docs.lead_paragraph: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association said yesterday that it would terminate the licenses of Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield if the Ohio plan proceeded with a $299.5 million agreement to sell its main lines of business to the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's biggest investor-owned hospital chain. Analysts called it a warning to Blue Cross plans across the country not to try to auction themselves off to hospital chains or other well-heeled bidders outside the Blue Cross system.

headline.main: Blue Cross Warns Ohio Plan Not to Sell to Columbia

docs.lead_paragraph: He led a spare and tattered life of need on the fringes of the city, but mostly he seemed to occupy some other world accessible only to himself. John J. Royster moved through the universe of homelessness and food stamps and city refuges in a solemn and circumscribed nether life. He is a man who appeared to avoid saying much to anyone, who up until yesterday had never been accused of any criminal act beyond vaulting over a subway turnstile.

headline.main: For Suspect, a Nether Life Spent on Fringes of the City
headline.kicker: A TRAIL OF VIOLENCE: THE SUSPECT

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is specious for Speaker Newt Gingrich to argue (letter, June 9) that the Republican Medicare proposal covers the costs of the program. He reaches this conclusion by using the Consumer Price Index to calculate the inflation rate for the program.

headline.main: Weighing Political Words and Political Action;On Medicare Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: In a striking sign that formal recognition of homosexual relationships is emerging as a bitter political flash point, the Southern Baptist Convention voted today to censure the Walt Disney Company in part for having adopted a policy last year extending health insurance benefits to the same-sex partners of employees. The resolution, adopted overwhelmingly by the nearly 14,000 people attending the denomination's annual meeting in the Superdome here, stopped short of calling for an immediate boycott of the entertainment giant by the nation's nearly 16 million Southern Baptists.

headline.main: Baptists Censure Disney For Gay-Spouse Benefits

docs.lead_paragraph: IF legislation giving workers the right to keep their health insurance when they change jobs breathes its last, the cause of death will almost certainly be a political stalemate over medical savings accounts. But is this idea, so loved by House Republicans and so detested by the White House, really worth the fuss? Not according to researchers at the Rand Corporation led by Emmett Keeler, whose report in the Journal of the American Medical Association last week suggested that the tax-sheltered accounts created by the House bill would have little effect on either total outlays for health care by people under age 65 or on accessibility of insurance for the very sick. And not according to Joe Newhouse at the Kennedy School of Government, who argues that the politicians are fighting over ways to improve a health care delivery system -- fee for service -- that is rapidly fading. "This debate is largely symbolic," he concludes.

headline.main: Economic Scene;Medical savings accounts: a solution without a problem?

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House is about to be blown to smithereens. In a new movie to be released on Independence Day, called "Independence Day," the White House is shown quietly at night when suddenly it explodes into a big orange fireball. It is detonated by space aliens, not by Republicans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several former National Basketball Association players, including ALEX ENGLISH, DAVE COWENS, OSCAR ROBERTSON and JERRY WEST, gathered yesterday without a basketball in sight. They were in Manhattan to announce the first marketing venture of an organization known as XPRO, the association of retired professional basketball players. XPRO was formed to create a support system for the hundreds of former players who pioneered and popularized the game before the existence of adequate pension plans. Yesterday it announced a deal with Whitehall-Robins Healthcare's Anacin brand pain reliever, which will provide XPRO with funds to assist its 525 members and their families through scholarships, insurance programs and health care benefits. A television advertising campaign will feature the former players BILL WALTON, BOB COUSY, Cowens, Robertson and West. "Before, we could only use the super superstars like LARRY BIRD for marketing purposes," said English, the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association and former eight-time N.B.A. All-Star. "This gives us the opportunity to market the players that were in the trenches and really built this league."
